Mariée et mère de deux enfants, madame A. Ama est née en 1966 à Atakpamé dans la région des plateaux. Elle a pour activité la vente de boubou et de charbon de bois dans le quartier d’Agoè. Elle vient toujours en aide à son mari qui a un revenu très faible.  Toutefois elle a ajouté à son activité la vente de jus de fruit et de glaçon.
Actuellement son stock de charbon de bois est presque épuisé et elle désire le refaire. 
A cet effet, elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 18 sacs de charbons de bois et 30 boubous de femmes.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of two children, Mrs. Ama A. was born in 1966 in Atakpamé in the plateau region. Her business is selling boubous (traditional loose robes) and charcoal in the Agoè area. She always wants to help her husband whose income is meager. She has also added sales of fruit juice and ice cubes to her business.

Presently, she is almost out of charcoal and she would like to stock up. For this purpose, she is requesting her first loan to buy 18 sacks of charcoal and 30 boubous for women.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of boubous and charcoal

loans.name: Gina Filipe

texts.pt:
Gina Filipe C. nasceu na província de Maputo, tem 38 anos de idade, solteira, mãe de 3 filhos com idade entre 20, 13 e 8 anos de idade respectivamente. Apenas sustenta a sua família.

Gina estudou até 9ªclasse e parou quando ficou grávida, gina vive basicamente de negocio de venda de malas de madeiras quais adquira por 1500,00mt lá no centro do pais e vende na cidade de Maputo por 5000,00mt. Com isso tem tida um rendimento mensal de 30000,00mt.

Este é o primeiro empréstimo da Gina na Hluvuku e no Kiva e já teve no valor de 12.000,00mt na associação de credito e aplicou na venda de verduras negocio que não deu bons resultados. Assim com este empréstimo de 18.000,00mt pretende reforçar o estoque.

Tem como planos futuros a construção de uma casa condigna dado que neste momento vive numa dependência e também pretende comprar um carro e tudo conta com ajuda do credito.
texts.en:
Gina Filipe C. was born in the province of Maputo, is 38 years old, single, and mother of 3 children with ages between 8 and 20 respectively. She only supports her family. Gina attended school until the 9th grade, and she stopped when she became pregnant. Gina lives basically by selling wooden chests which she acquires for 1,500MT in the center of the country and then sells in the city of Maputo for 5,000MT. With this she has had a monthly income of 30,000MT. This is her first loan through Hluvuku and Kiva, but she already had a loan for 12,000MT with the credit association that she applied to a vegetable sales business that did not have good results. With this loan of 18,000MT she intends to replenish her stocks. She has future plans to construct a suitable home given that in this moment she lives in a rental. She also intends to purchase a car, and everything counts on the help of credit.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wooden chests for resale

loans.name: Laurinda  Raul

texts.pt:
Laurinda Raul Ngenha nasceu na província de Maputo distrito de Manhiça ao sul de Moçambique, tem 42 anos de idade, é divorciada e mãe de 3 filhos com idade entre 21, 18 e 15 anos respectivamente. Apenas sustenta os seus filhos.

Laurinda estudou até 2ªclasse e parou por falta de condições financeiras foi criada pela mãe separada e eram 12 irmãos,  aos 18 anos teve o seu primeiro filho e aos 20 anos se casou maritalmente, marido que vieram a separar se em 1993, 3 anos depois de se mudar do distrito de Manhiça para cidade de Maputo. Antes de mudar se já praticava o negocio onde passou de vários no incio vendia carvão, depois vendia ovos e mais tarde começa a vende de cereais e este continua até data hoje.

Laurinda vive basicamente de negocio de venda de cerais  e leguminosas e nao tem empregado apenas contracta temporariamente para o carregamento. Os principais cereais que vende são Milho, Feijão e amendoim, onde adquira a lata de amendoim 200,00mt e vende por 450,00mt. Tem tido rendimento mensal de 18.000,00mt a 20.000,00mt. Nao faz poupança bancária periódico apenas uma poupança vulgarmente chamado por Xitique que consistem numa pagamente de todos contra todos, sendo uma de cada vez.

Assim Laurinda pretende com este empréstimo aumentar o volume do seu negocio. Tem planos para futuro a construção de dependências uma vez que tem um quintal muito garnde.
texts.en:
Laurinda Raul Ngenha was born in the province of Maputo, district of Manhiça, in the south of Mozambique. She is 42 years old, divorced, and the mother of 3 children with ages between 15 and 21. She only supports her children. Laurinda studied until the 2nd grade and stopped for a lack of financial conditions. She was raised by her mother who was separated, along with 12 siblings. When she was 18 years old she had her first child, and at 20 she was married. She separated in 1993 3 years after moving from the Manhiça district to the city of Maputo. Before moving she was already in business selling coal, but she moved on to sell eggs and later began to sell grains and cereals which she continues to sell today. Laurinda lives basically selling grains and legumes. She does not have any employees except for contracting temporarily for shipments. The principal foods that she sells are corn, beans, and peanuts. She acquires a can of peanuts for 200MT and sells it for 450MT. She has had a monthly income of between 18,000MT to 20,000MT. She does not make periodic bank savings, only a common saving called Xitique that consists of a payment of all against all, being one each time. Laurinda intends to use this loan to increase the volume of her business. She has future plans to construct some rooms once she has a big enough yard.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grains for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in a large stock of goods to add to her newly started grocery store.

loans.name: Paola

texts.es:
Paola es D. la tercera edad, pero es una señora muy trabajadora que esta en perfecto estado D. salud. Confecciona guantes D. lana D. alpaca y llama manualmente, vive  en la zona Progreso (ciudad D. El Alto) con su nieta D. 16 años y su esposo en una casa como cuidadora, no paga alquiler . El esposo trabaja D. portero, dicha ocupación es la principal fuente D. ingreso que cubre los gastos familiares. 

Por su edad le negaron créditos en otras instituciones.

Es por eso que con su ayuda Paola piensa usar el l crédito para  comprar materia prima (lana D. alpaca y llama) ya que desea impulsar su negocio incrementando su producción

Es su tercer crédito  con IMPRO, su buen comportamiento D. pago le permite acceder a otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Paola is an elderly woman, but she is a very hardworking lady who is in perfect health. She makes gloves from alpaca and llama wool by hand. She lives in the zone Progreso (city of El Alto) with her 16-year-old granddaughter and her husband in a house as a caretaker; she does not pay rent. Her husband works as a doorman, and this occupation is the principal source of income that covers the family expenses. Because of her age, she has been denied loads from other institutions. With your help, Paola plans to use her loan in order to buy raw materials (alpaca and llama wool) that she wants to kick-start her business by increasing production.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Genaro

texts.es:
Genaro es productor de leche de vaca, dicho producto es vendido  a la empresa procesadora de leche PIL para su transformación en derivados lácteos. También trabaja como pequeño agricultor, ambas actividades le sirven para mantener a su familia (dos hijos y esposa); vive en la Provincia Omasuyo Achacachi – Tipampa (a tres horas de la ciudad de La Paz).

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una vaca lechera de mediana calidad, planea vender mayor cantidad de leche.

 Es el primer crédito  con IMPRO, nuestra evaluación nos diche que  califica para ser beneficiado con el préstamo
texts.en:
Genaro is a dairy farmer who sells cow's milk to the Bolivian dairy company Pil, which then uses the milk to produce different dairy products. Genaro also works as a small-scale farmer; both activities help him support his wife and two children. Gernaro lives in the Omasuyo Achacachi de Tipampa Province, about three hours outside of the city of La Paz.

He will use this loan to buy a milk cow of average quality so that he can produce and sell more milk. This is his first loan from IMPRO; he has been approved for this credit based on an evaluation conducted by the institution.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a milk cow

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio trabaja como chofer de servicio publico en el Trufi 88 (Sindicato Eduardo Avaroa), es su principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre los gastos familiares (esposa e hijo pequeño). Vive en la casa de sus padres ubicada en la zona Pasankeri, ladera de la ciudad de La Paz.

El crédito lo destinara para la transformación de gasolina a gas natural comprimido en su herramienta de trabajo.

Es su primer con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada permite aprobar la solicitud de Julio Cesar.
texts.en:
Julio works as a public transit driver in the Trufi 88 (Sindicato Eduardo Avaroa). This is his primary source of income with which he covers the family expenses (he has a wife and a small child.) He lives in his parents’ home, which is located in the zone Pasankeri, on the hillside of the city of La Paz. This loan would be used to change from gasoline to compressed natural gas for his working tool. This is his first loan with IMPRO; the qualification test approved the request from Julio Cesar.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Change Taxi Fuel to Natural Gas

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth Q. trabaja como comerciante de golosinas y es estudiante de enfermería (profesión que ejerce a medio tiempo) con el primer trabajo cubre sus estudios. Vive en la casa de su madre ubicada en la Zona Villa Huayna Potosi de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinara para incrementar sus capital de trabajo (mercaderia). Si incrementa sus ingresos podrá tomar más materias, terminar la carrera de enfermería en menos tiempo, dedicarse completamente a esta profesión y ganar más dinero en el futuro
Es su segundo crédito via Kiva, su buen comportamiento de pago le permite acceder a otro préstamo
texts.en:
Elizabeth Q. works selling sweets and is also a nursing student. She works part-time as a nurse, and is able to pay for her studies by selling sweets. She lives in her mother's house in the Villa Huayna Potosi neighborhood in the city of El Alto, Bolivia.

Elizabeth will use this loan to buy more merchandise for her business. If she can earn more, she will be able to take more courses so that she can finish her studies sooner, begin to work full-time as a nurse and start to earn more money.

This is her second loan from Kiva. She paid off her first loan in full and on time, which is why she was approved for a second loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sweets to sell to pay for nursing school

loans.name: Javier

texts.es:
Javier M. trabaja como costurero, confecciona chamarras para varones. Este  joven soltero destina sus ingresos en su educación y apoya a sus padres en la manutención de sus hermano menores. Actualmente vive en la casa sus padres ubicada en la zona Villa Juliana (una ladera de la  Ciudad de El Alto). 

El crédito será invertido para su traslado a otra casa donde pagará un anticrético (especie de renta de un lugar por un período de tiempo determinado) ya que su domicilio actual resulta muy pequeña para toda su familia, de esa forma podrá tener con mayor comodidad y un taller de costura más grande.
 
Es su segundo crédito con IMPRO, su buen comportamiento de pago le permite acceder a otro  préstamo.
texts.en:
Javier M. works as a tailor, making mens jackets. This single youth uses his income for his education and he supports his parents in the maintenance of his younger brother. At present he lives in his parents house located in the Villa Juliana zone (a suburb of the City of El Alto).

The loan will be invested in moving to another house where he will pay an 'anticrético' (a type of rent for a place for a specific time period) since his current residence turns out to be very small for all of his family. In that way he will be able to have greater comfort and a larger tailor shop.

This is his second loan with IMPRO. His good payment history allows us to agree to another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To move to a larger house with a larger area for his tailor shop.

loans.name: Blanca Julieta

texts.es: La Señora Blanca M. D. Rondon es cliente D. Emprender desD. al año 2003, ella comenzó	solicitando un credito con el monto D. 150 dólares en un grupo solidario D. tres personas, posteriormente despues D. cuatro secuencias decidió individualzarse para optar a créditos con mayor monto. Ella es propietaria D. un salón D. peluquería desD. hace 20 años, por lo que cuenta con una amplia clientela que solicita sus servicios, en particular en el campo D. la depilación pues esta es su especialidad. Cabe  señalar que la señora tiene una hija profesional y fruto D. sus esfuerzos continúa apoyandola para comenzar con su profesión, la cual se desenvuelve en el campo D. la salud. La señora Blanca M., se encuentra en su novena secuencia con crédito individual,demostrando	responsabilidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Blanca M. D. Rondon has been a client of Emprender since 2003. Her first loan was for $150 as a member of a three-person solidarity group. After completing four loan cycles with the group, she decided to take out a larger, individual loan. She has run a hair salon for the past 20 years, and has a wiD. range of customers who request her services, particularly for waxings, which is her specialty. It should be noted that her daughter is a young professional, and thanks to Mrs. M.'s continual support she is launching her career in the field of medicine. Mrs. Blanca M. is now taking out her ninth individual loan. She has always been very repsonsible making her repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for hair salon

loans.name: Edgar Reynaldo

texts.es:
Reynaldo trabaja como chofer de servicio publico en el Trufi 88 (Sindicato Eduardo Avaroa), es su principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre los la manutención de sus dos pequeñas hijas que están estudiando en la escuela estatal, la esposa sólo se dedica a las labores domesticas. La pareja paga el alquiler de una casa ubicada en la zona de  Satélite de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinara para transformar el sistema de gasolina a gas natural comprimido de su automóvil, se estima que podrá ahorrar un  40% de lo que gastaba en combustible.

Es su primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarla solicitud de Reynaldo.
texts.en:
Reynaldo works in public transportation as a driver for the Trufi 88 route (trufis are taxis that operate like buses, with fixed routes). He belongs to the Eduardo Avaroa union. This is his main source of income, with which he supports his two young daughters, who both attend public school. His wife only works at home. The couple rents a home in the Satellite City neighborhood of El Alto, Bolivia.

Reynaldo plans to use this loan to convert his trufi to run on compressed natural gas instead of gasoline. He estimates that by doing so, he will save 40% of what he currently spends to fill his tank.

This is his first credit with IMPRO; he has been approved for the loan based on a credit evaluation conducted by the institution.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Convert vehicle to run on natural gas

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
Rolando trabaja como chofer asalariado en el Trufi 88 (Sindicato Eduardo Avaroa), su esposa es operaria en un taller de costuras,con ambas ocupaciones pueden cubrir los gastos familiares. La familia paga el alquiler de una casa ubicada en la zona Villa Ingavi de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito será usado para que Rolando adquiera otra herramienta de trabajo (vehículo  a medio uso que servirá como taxi), misma que será de su entera propiedad, lo que le permitrá incrementar sus ingresos económicos.

Es el segundo crédito con IMPRO, su buen comportamiento de pago le permite acceder a otro prestamo.
texts.en:
Rolando works as a salaried driver in the Trufi 88 (Sindicato Eduardo Avaroa). His wife is an operator in a clothing factory; with these occupations they are able to cover the family expenses. The family pays to rent a house located in the zone Villa Ingavi in the city of El Alto. The loan would be used for Rolando to acquire a different working tool (a vehicle to be used in service as a taxi). This would be entirely his own property, which would permit him to increase his income. This is his second loan with IMPRO; his good payment history permitted him to continue with another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a taxi

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.es:
Adelaida trabaja como comerciante de frutas, su marido es portero de una empresa. La pareja mantiene a 4 hijos, de los cuales la mayor esta a punto de ser bachiller. La familia tiene casa propia que fue beneficiada con un crédito anterior, el domicilio esta ubicado en la zona Villa Tahuntinsuyo de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo (mercaderia) de esa forma incrementar sus ingresos económicos.

Es el segundo crédito via Kiva, sus impecables antecedentes favorecen esta solicitud de préstamo
texts.en:
Adelaida sells fruit, and her husband works as a doorman for a local company. The couple supports their four children, the oldest of whom will soon finish high school. The family owns their own home in the Villa Tahuntinsuyo neighborhood of the city of El Alto. They bought the home with a previous loan.

The loan will be used to buy more fruit to sell so that the couple can earn more.

This is Adelaida's second Kiva loan; her impeccable credit history makes her an excellent candidate to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Maria del Carmen C. administra la tienda que tenía su madre en su domicilio ubicado en la zona de achumani de la ciudad de La Paz, Bolivia, al ver que ninguno de sus hermanos mayores quería hacerce cargo de la tienda, se ve en la necesidad de atenderla sola, siendo esta el sustento de su familia mientras sus hermanos culminen sus estudios universitarios. Ya han pasado 20 años desde que ella se hizo cargo de la tienda y en base a sacrificio atiende su negocio desde las 5 de la madrugada hasta las cero horas del día siguiente. Hoy por hoy su tienda es un Almacen bien surtido, cuyo principal servicio es la venta de productos de Coca Cola repartiendo el producto a toda la zona en particular a salones de eventos sociales. Es una persona muy sacrificada y trabajadora, y muy responsable en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Señora Maria del Carmen C. runs the store that her mother has located in her home, in the zone Achumani in the city of La Paz, Bolivia. She saw that none of her elder siblings wanted to take on the store, and so she felt the necessity of attending it alone, being the supporter of the family while her siblings finished their university studies. Now 20 years has passed since she took charge of the store, and her sacrificing commitment to the store means that she works from 5 in the morning until the wee small hours of the next day. At the moment her store is well stocked, with a principal focus in the sale of Coca Cola products, distributing the product to the entire area, in particular locations with social events. She is a very sacrificing and hardworking woman, and is very responsible in the repayment of her loans.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Aia

texts.en:
Aia T., 39, is married with 3 children. She has 2 years of experience in the canteen business. She sells to the village people and the public 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Aia has one previous loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are Aia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. All of the loan will be used to fund her business. Aia is a young mother aiming to be successful in the future.

loans.use: Purchase chips, popcorn, twisties, and drinks

loans.name: Ipu

texts.en:
Ipu F., 50, is married with 8 children. She has three years of experience in the taxi service business. She runs the taxi 6 days per week and she expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Ipu has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Ipu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be use to buy petrol and strung oil for the taxi. Sometimes when she felt sick then her husband will help her in operating the taxi business.

loans.use: Purchase strung oil and petrol

loans.name: Adela Albina

texts.es:
La señora Adela R. es cliente antigua, comenzó a trabajar con nosotros casi desde la fundación de Emprender primero en grupo solidario y posteriemente desde el año 2003 se individualizo como cliente empezando con un crédito de 500 dólares, a la fecha solicita un préstamo de 7000 Bs. Para incrementar su capital de trabajo y comprar los productos e insumos para repostería, la señora es una cliente muy dinámica, hasta hace poco tenía un contrato con el Colegio	
Loretto de la ciudad de La Paz para la producción y venta de desayunos en mencionado centro educativo, a su vez reparte sus productos en distintos establecimientos y oficinas de la zona sur de la ciudad, tiene dos hijos que le colaboran y que ya salieron profesionales, su	esposo trabaja en una compañía de electricidad, viajando constantemente. Actualmente presenta un historial de puntualidad y responsabilidad en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adela R. is a long-time member who started working with us almost since the founding of Emprender, first in a solidarity group, then in 2003 as an individual client. She stared with a loan of $500.00 USD, but she is currently requesting a 7,000.00 BOB loan in order to increase her work capital and purchase the products and supplies she needs for her bakery. She is a very dynamic customer who, until recently, had a contract with Colegio Loretto school in the city of La Paz to make and sell breakfast in this educational center. She concurrently delivers her baked goods throughout different institutions and offices in the southern area of the city. She has two children who collaborate with her and who are now professionals. Her husband works for an electric company, so he is constantly traveling. Up to now, she has had a history of payment punctuality and responsibility with our institute.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Faamanuiaga

texts.en:
Faamanuiaga T., 43, is married with 7 children. She has 3 years of experience selling BBQ and pancakes to the village people and the public. She sells 6 days per week and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Faamanuiaga has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. All of the loan will be use to fund her business. Faamanuiaga's husband will help her operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase mutton flaps, chicken franks, soya, onions, and salt

loans.name: Motiana

texts.en:
Motiana I., 49, is married with 6 children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Motiana has two previous loans from SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy chemicals, fertilizer, weed killer and bush knives. Her husband is helping her operating the business.

loans.use: Purchase  axe, chemicals, sack of fertilizer, weed killer and bush knives

loans.name: Fouai

texts.en:
Fouai T., 38, is married with 1 child.  She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells taro, taamu, and  bananas to the village people and the public 2 days per week. Fouai's husband helps her operate the business. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  

Fouai has 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Fouai's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with a traditional bank. The loan will be used to fund her business.

loans.use: Purchase taro tubers, knives, chemicals, and pesticides

loans.name: Komi

texts.en:
Komi T. is 62 years old. She is married with 6 children. She has two years of experience selling ice cake and popcorn to the general public. She sells 7 days per week and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250USD).

Komi has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Komi's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. As a 62-year-old mother running a popcorn business, Komi is very happy to earn her own money.

loans.use: Purchase cordial, sugar, pots, foam cups, corn seeds, salt, cooking oil, and popcorn maker.

loans.name: Fetulima

texts.en:
Fetulima K., 48, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience running a shop where she sells to the general public 7 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1020 Tala (~425 USD).

Fetulima has three previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Fetulima is an established member of the program running a shop in her village, and she aims to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, chicken, mutton flaps, noodles (ramen), lollies, twisties, bongos, mosquito coils, etc.

loans.name: Fouai

texts.en:
Fouai T., 38, is married with one child. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells taro, taamu, and bananas to the village people and the public 2 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

Fouai has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy equipment such as knives, chemicals, and pesticides. Her husband will help her operate the business.

loans.use: Purchase taro tubers, knives, chemicals, and pesticides

loans.name: Faumuina

texts.en:
Faumuina S., 61, is married with 11 children. She has many years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers two days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

Faumuina has 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She a very energetic mother, and her children and grandchildren are working for her in running the business.

loans.use: Purchase sting, weed killer, gromozone, barrier fence, wheelbarrow, and taro tops.

loans.name: Kaloline

texts.en:
Kaloline E. is 51 years old and is married with 6 children. She has 4 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells taro, taamu, and bananas to the village people and the public 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).

Kaloline has 4 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase equipment for her plantation business, including knives, pesticides, and chemicals. Kaloline's husband will help her in operating the business.

loans.use: Purchase taro tubers, knives, chemicals, and pesticides

loans.name: Lise

texts.en:
Lise F., 52, is married with 4 children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells taro, taamu, and bananas to the village people and the public 2 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be Tala (~300 USD). Lise's husband helps her operate the business.

Lise has 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy things she needs for her business, including knives, fertilizers, pesticides, and taro tubers.

loans.use: Purchase taro tubers, knives, fertilizers, and pesticides.

loans.name: Faauuga

texts.en:
Faauuga L., 42, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the retail business. She sells to the general public and villagers from her shop 6 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 680 Tala (~283 USD).

Faauuga has 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase flour, sugar, onions, yeast, soya sauce, lamp flaps, chicken, fish, and soap for her store.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, onions, yeast, soya sauce, lamp flaps, chicken, fish, and soap

loans.name: Pasi

texts.en:
Pasi L., 35, is married with 4 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fishing business. Her husband is one of the most skillful fishermen in the village, and he helps Pasi with the business. Pasi sells to the village people and the public 2 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 Tala (~41 USD).

Pasi has two previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. The loan will be use to buy an extra canoe, fishing net, spear, and goggles for the business.

loans.use: Purchase canoe, fishing net, spear, and goggles

loans.name: Avalisa

texts.en:
Avalisa S., 43, is married with 3 children. She has 5 years of experience in the food and clothing business. She sells to the village people and the public 4 days per week. Her husband helps her operate the business. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Avalisa has 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Avalisa's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy freezers and snack food for the store, and also to buy cement for home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase freezers and food supplies for the retail store, and cement for home improvement

loans.name: Masi

texts.en:
Masi S., 36, is married with 5 children. She has 4 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the village people and the public 2 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).

Masi has 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Masi's only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with a traditional bank. Her loan will be used to buy cotton material, thread, and needles, along with a new sewing machine to replace her old one.

loans.use: Purchase cotton material, thread, needles, and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Faafetai F., 56, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in her business. She sells to the general public and villagers 6 days per week. Faafetai has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 520 Tala (~$216 USD). SPBD loans are Faafetai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She runs a small shop in her village, and there is some very tough competition for her but she tries to have good customer service to get her clients.

loans.use: Faafetai would like to improve her general store.

loans.name: Chorolque Group

texts.es: En la carretera 6 de marzo de la ciudad de El Alto, se  encuentra ubicado el centro focal de Senkata a éste pertenece la asociación “Chorolque” que trabajo junto a Pro-Mujer   hace un año aproximadamente. Casadas en su mayoría y con un promedio de cuatro hijos cada una. A primeras horas de  la mañana  el trabajo para la asociación “Chorolque” comienza, encontraron en la elaboración de comida  una actividad muy lucrativa ya que anteriormente de dedicaban a otro tipo de negocio que no produjo la rentabilidad esperada, Alejandrina por ejemplo tiene un kiosco  en la Av. 6 de marzo cerca de la Tranca de Senkata, donde ofrece dulces, refrescos, empanadas y otros; Marisol tiene un puesto, donde elabora comida rápida, es decir ella ofrece a su clientela, salchipapas, pollo dorado, hamburguesas, tucumanas y rellenos de papa; Guadalupe elabora las tradicionales llauchas ( empanadas al horno de queso) que las vende de manera ambulante por las calles de la ciudad. Todas tiene el sueño de mejorar en sus pequeños negocios por lo que necesitan créditos para comprar insumos en mayor cantidad, de éste modo incrementar ventas para generar mayores ingresos, en beneficio de sus familias.
texts.en:
The Senkata center, which pertains to the “Chorolque” association that has been working with Pro-Mujer for about a year, is located on highway 6 de marzo in the city of El Alto. Most members are married and have an average of about 4 children each. Work for the “Chorolque” association starts very early in the morning. The members found food sales to be very lucrative. They were previously involved in another type of business, but it did not turn out to be as lucrative as expected. Alejandrina owns a stand on 6 de marzo Avenue (near Senkata) in which she sells candy, soft drinks, empanadas, and more. Marisol owns a stand in which she prepares and sells fast food, such as salichipapas (street food that consists of fries and sausages), fried chicken, hamburgers, tucumanas (fried pastry stuffed with meat and vegetables), and stuffed mashed potatoes. Guadalupe makes traditional llauchas (oven-baked cheese empanadas), which she sells on the city streets. They all have the dream of improving their small businesses, which is why they need loans so that they can purchase supplies in greater quantities, thus they can increase sales and generate more profits, which will benefit their families.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase greater quantities of supplies

loans.name: Clavel Group

texts.es:
La asociación “Clavel” trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer en el centro focal de Villa Adela hace cuatro años. En su mayoría son casadas y con familias numerosas. Todas se dedican al comercio;algunas de dedican a la venta de  variedad de ropa y medias, que son comercializadas en los yungas,por otro lado, Flora vende sandalias, pantuflas y papel higiénico; Naldy, Isabel y Ross tienen tiendas de barrio. Cuentan que ahora es imprescindible que ellas tengan un negocio propio ya que los sueldos de sus esposos no son suficientes para mantener a sus familias, ya que las necesidades de sus niños crecen cada día más.
Necesitan de capital para comprar productos al por mayor, de esta manera sus ganancias serán mayores
texts.en:
The “Clavel” (Carnation) association has been working in conjunction with Pro-Mujer in Villa Adela for four years. Most of its members are married and have big families. They all have their own businesses. Some sell a variety of clothing and hosiery in the yungas—the Eastern part of the Andes Mountains. Flora, on the other hand, sells sandals, slippers, and bathroom tissue, while Naldy, Isabel, and Rossy run neighborhood general stores. They say that it is imperative that they have their own businesses because their husbands’ wages are insufficient to support their families, and their children grow more and more each day. They need capital to purchase wholesale products so that they may earn bigger profits.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale products

loans.name: Dulce Maria's Group

texts.en:
Dulce Maria is married with two daughters, one of whom attends school.  Her husband is doing military service at Cotuí, in the province of Sanchez Ramirez in the central part of the country.  To supplement her family's income, Dulce sells an assortment of cosmetics to women in her neighborhood.  She has been selling these goods for more than five years, and currently she has a well-established clientele.  The entrepreneur has requested a loan to add new and exclusive products to her inventory.  That way, she'll be able to increase her earnings and improve her family's life.

These are the women who'll receive the loan together with Dulce Maria:
Rafaela S. S., who'll invest in beauty products for her small business;
Teofila Gonzalez Sanchez, to purchase women's clothing to retail;
Claudina Morel Otanez, who operates a small fruit and vegetable stand; and
Maritza Reyes Hilario, who owns a small grocery store.

Pictured from left to right are Rafaela, Dulce Maria, Teofila, Claudina and Maritza.

loans.use: To invest in new cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Gogosina

texts.en: Gogosina T., 26, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the furniture shop business. She sells to the general public and villagers 5 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 800 Tala (~$333 USD). SPBD loans are Gogosina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband does the furniture, but she helps out.

loans.use: Gogosina would like to purchase sand paper, varnish, paint, hammer, nails, gloves and timber for her business.

loans.name: Mrs. Nharn Pha's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank, which consists of fifteen people, is located in Angkrorng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Nharn P. is the village bank president who was selected by the members. She is a breeder who raises four cows, and she also makes mats. Her husband, Mr. Leng Eng, has a plot of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. Although they have different businesses, they still cannot support their family, so Mrs. Nharn P. decided to ask for a loan to buy three piglets in order to start a pig breeding business. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her pigs. Mrs. Nharn P. is 51 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and another who helps the father on the plantation. The remaining two are attending the local school. All the members are shown in the picture but one among the fifteen is blocked.

This is a village bank loan. The village bank mainly has end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. The EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy three piglets in order to start a pig breeding business.

loans.name: Mrs. Cheb Nan's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people in Tropeang Srongae Village in Kampong Chhnang Province make up the village bank loan. They plan to use the loan which they obtain for different purposes. Mrs. Cheb N. is the village bank president and a breeder who raises two cows and a pig. Aside from these businesses, she also makes a big pot which is made from cement. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more cement to make more big pots to fulfill her customers' demands. Mrs. Cheb N. is 32 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Fourteen members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. These loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To purchase more cement to invent more big pots to fulfill her customers' demands.

loans.name: Mr. Hun Tan's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan which is located in Tbeng Khpos Village in Kampong Chhnang Province consists of nine people. They will use the loan which they obtain for different purposes. Mr. Hun T. is the village bank president and a farmer who owns two-hectare to cultivate rice. Aside from this, he is a construction worker who can make a small income to support his household. His wife, Mrs. On Nam, helps him on the plantation. On this plantation, they face a problem because their field is infertile which affects their crops. To solve this problem, Mr. Hun T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field in order to make their crops more productive. Mr. Hun T. is 53 years old and the father of a child who is attending the local school. Two men among the three have come to get a loan instead of their wives because they are busy with their work.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. The EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the field in order to make their crops more productive.

loans.name: Faasulu

texts.en: Faasulu E., 43, is married with eight children. She has 2 years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the public and village people 6 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~$125 USD). SPBD loans are Faasulu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy a new sewing machine to replace the old one, threads and cotton materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: Faasulu would like to buy a new sewing machine, threads and cotton materials for her business.

loans.name: Suluvale

texts.en: Suluvale R., 55, is married with six children. She has 4 years of experience as a shop owner. She sells to the village people and public 6 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Suluvale's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan that she borrowed from SPBD will be used to buy a freezer and snack foods for the shop.

loans.use: Suluvale would like to purchase a freezer and snack food for her shop.

loans.name: Ia

texts.en: Ia I., 43, is married with four children. She has 5 years of experience in the bingo/taxi business. She conducts her bingo game 2 days per week, while her taxi works 7 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD. Ia expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~$208 USD). SPBD loans are Ia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy car parts to repair her taxi and also to purchase bingo materials.

loans.use: Ia would like to purchase bingo materials, taxi tyres and spare parts.

loans.name: Mrs. Prak Sok Art's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan in Krang Leav Village in Kampong Chhnang Province consists of eighteen people. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Prak S. A. is the village bank president, and she is a fruit seller in the local market. Aside from this business, she is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it, S. she decided to ask for a loan to buy two more pigs for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Thon Thuren, is a construction worker who can make a small income to support his family. Mrs. Prak S. A. is 50 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom sells firewood and another, the youngest, attends the local school. Mrs. Hem Chantha is a group guarantor and is alS. presented in the picture. All of the members are shown in the picture but two of them are blocked.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Seventeen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. The EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients stA. to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy two more pigs for breeding.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Suiti

texts.en: Suiti K., 42, is married with four children. She has 3 years of experience in the vegetable and plantation business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~$187 USD). SPBD loans are Suiti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy farming equipment, knives, pesticides and vegetable seeds.

loans.use: Suiti would like to purchase farming equipment, chemicals, pesticides and vegetable seeds for her farm.

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en: Sofia F., 28, is married with five children. She has 4 years of experience in the BBQ business. She sells to the village people and public 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~$83 USD). SPBD loans are Sofia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase mutton flaps, chicken franks, onions, soya and salt. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: Sofia would like to purchase Mutton flaps, chicken franks, soya, onions and salt for her BBQ business.

loans.name: Faisealofa

texts.en: Faisealofa V., 42, is married with six children. She has 1 year of experience in the buns and donuts business. She sells to the village people and public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Faisealofa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy flour, sugar, yeast, plastic bags and other ingredients used in her bakery. Her older daughter helps her with the business.

loans.use: Faisealofa would like to purchase flour, sugar, yeast, icing and plastic bags.

loans.name: Tailelei

texts.en: Tailelei S., 47, is married with four children. She has 2 years of experience in the banana chips business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Tailelei's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase goods for the shop, clothes and vegetable oil for the banana chips business. Her husband and children helps her with the business.

loans.use: Tailelei would like to purchase goods, clothes and vegetable oils for her banana chips shop.

loans.name: Oneone

texts.en: Oneone M., 42, is married with three children. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation of taro taamu and  banana business. She sells to the village people and public 6 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Oneone's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy farming equipment, chemicals, pesticides and seedlings for the plantation. Her husband and children will support her business.

loans.use: Oneone would like to purchase farming equipment, chemicals, pesticides and seedlings.

loans.name: Faatupu

texts.en: Faatupu A., 46, is married with seven children. She has 1 year of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Faatupu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase fabric materials and a new sewing machine. Her husband and her children help her with the business.

loans.use: Faatupu would like to purchase to buy fabric materials and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Asoiva

texts.en: Asoiva F., 30, is married with four children. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation of taro taamu and  banana business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Asoiva's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy farming equipments, chemicals, pesticides and seedlings, while the rest of the money will be used to buy timber, iron roofs and cement for home improvement.

loans.use: Asoiva would like to purchase farming equipment, chemicals, pesticides and seedlings and home improvement.

loans.name: Sialuga

texts.en: Sialuga N., 45, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in the plantation and vegetable garden business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Sialuga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Sialuga is a very energetic mother who loves to keep herself busy. Her business has grown so much that their whole family is relying on it for their major income.

loans.use: Sialuga would like to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, weedkiller, fungicide, and a backpack sprayer for her farm.

loans.name: Filifili

texts.en: Filifili P., 42, is married with four children. She has 2 years of experience in the bakery business. She sells to the village people and public 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~$166 USD). SPBD loans are Filifili's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy ingredients needed for her baking and a new electric oven. Her husband helps her with the business.

loans.use: Filifili would like to buy ingredients like flour, sugar, oil, and an electric oven for her bakery.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana M., 52, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the pig farming business. She sells to the general public and villagers 4 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~$250 USD). SPBD loans are Susana's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband and children are doing the farming, with her great support.

loans.use: Susana would like to purchase coconuts for pig food, old tyres for drinking water, and wire fence to put pigs inside.

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en:
Susitina F., 40, is married with four children.  She has three years of experience in the food market business. She sells to the village people, five days per week. She has had five previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD).  

SPBD loans are Susitina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy sacks of flour, mutton flaps, chicken legs, foam plates, foam cups, and soya for her business. Her husband is one of her great assistants in running her business.

loans.use: Purchase to buy sack of flour, mutton flaps, chicken leg, foam cups and soy-souce

loans.name: Lotu

texts.en:
Lotu K., 56 years old, is married with six children.  She has many years of experience in the restaurant business. She sells to the general public and villagers about six days per week. She has already had three previous loan with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (approximately 166 USD).  SPBD loans are Lotu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for her children's school fees. The rest of the money earned will be used to buy things necessary for her restaurant business. These include mutton flaps, chicken legs, soya, foam plates and foam cups.

loans.use: To purchase foam cups, foam plates, plastic bags, mutton flaps, chicken legs and soya for her restaurant business

loans.name: Pupu

texts.en:
Pupu V., 54 years old, is married with five children.  She has many years of experience with agricultural gardening business. She sells to the general public and villagers approximately five days per week. She has had three previous loans with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about 125 USD).  SPBD loans are Pupu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks in her community. She is a very energetic mother who runs a vegetable garden; she's aiming to expand her business with this requested loan.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds (e.g cucumber,tomatoes & vegetable,) fertilizers, weelbarrow ,gloves ,spade and wire fence for her vegetable garden business.

loans.name: Luafulu

texts.en: Luafulu N., 40, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers 4 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 950 Tala (~395 USD).  SPBD loans are Luafulu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of loan will be used to buy farming equipments like knives, weed killer and fertilizers and the rest will be used for maintenance of her house. Her husband and children will support her business.

loans.use: Purchase farming equipment, fertilizers and cement for home improvement

loans.name: Siloma

texts.en:
Siloma S., 38 years old, is married with six children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the villagers and other customers about two days per week. She has already had a number of other successful loan(s) with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 166 USD). SPBD loans are Siloma's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Siloma's husband is fully engaged with the business and helps out where he can.

loans.use: To purchase taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals, a shovel, bush knives and barred wrire for her taro and banana business.

loans.name: Asoono

texts.en: Asoono T., 42, is married with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Asoono's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to purchase farming supplies like weed killer, fertilizer, chain link wires and other farming materials. Her husband and children will help out in the farming business.

loans.use: Purchase weedkiller, fertilizer and chain link wires for fencing

loans.name: Faaaliga

texts.en:
Faaaliga S. is 49 years old and is married with seven children.  She has three years of experience selling pork buns. She sells to the general public and villagers approximately seven days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (approximately 104 USD). SPBD loans are Faaaliga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy a sack of flour, a sack of sugar, yeast, and onions. Her husband looks after their small taro and banana plantation which supports her business in economically weak times.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of flour, sack of sugar, onions, yeast, soya sauce for her pork buns business.

loans.name: Loimata

texts.en:
Loimata I. is 29 years old and is married with three children.  She has many years of experience selling taro and bananas. She sells to the villagers about three days per week. She has had three previous loans with SPBD as well.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about 145 USD). SPBD loans are Loimata's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She works hard to support her kids at school and attend church on a consistent basis. Her husband and her brothers are fully engaged with her business as well.

loans.use: To purchase taro tubers, weed killer, pesticides, chemicals, shovels, bushknives, and labour wages for her brothers helping her husband plant crops.

loans.name: Paese

texts.en:
Paese T., 46 years old, is married with six children.  She has four years of experience in sewing and elei printing. She sells to the general public and villagers approximately three days per week. She has already had one previous loan with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about 125 USD). SPBD loans are Paese's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy fabrics, thread, glitter, and a designed printed board for the elei printing.  Her husband works at Card Care Centre, which helps her in raising and supporting their large family.

loans.use: To purchase thread, materials, fabric paints, fabric glitters and a designed printing board.

loans.name: Viole

texts.en:
Viole S., 40 years old, is married with five children.  She has many year of experience in the groceries business. She sells to the villagers and public seven days per week. She has had seven previous loans with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (about 250 USD). SPBD loans are Viole's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She works hard to support her kids attend school and church.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of rice, flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, onions, Lollioes, a box of herring, a box of chicken ,sausage,mutton flaps,ice cream ,ice pop box of noodles, twisties candles, insects spray, mosquito coils, gel, laundry powder, laundry soap and shampoo.

loans.name: Mrs. Hem Chenda's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen members are part of the village bank loan in Andoung Svay Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Hem C., 48 years old, is the village bank president. She is a Khmer cake maker who earns a small income to support her family. Since this business is going well with a steady stream of customers, she would like to expand it. She has asked for a loan to buy sticky rice to make more Khmer cake to meet her customers' demands. Her husband, Mr. Srey Ched, is a construction worker who earns less than $2 per day to support his family. They have four children: two sell purified water; one is a construction worker; the youngest is attending the local school.

All of these members have end-of-term loans and they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time.

loans.use: To buy sticky rice

loans.name: Muhabat

texts.en:
Muhabat D. is a 56 year old woman. She is married with three adult children. They are all married and independent.

Muhabat owns a specialized fabrics store at the central market in Dushanbe City. Muhabat works in a sphere of trade where the demand is always very consistent and high, because the national dresses in Tajikistan are very popular and a very important item in the dowry of any girl. She is one of the leading fabrics vendors in the market where she works. She is very perseverant and determined in all of her business endeavors, which has helped to sustain her venture for 17 years. Muhabat has about $3,500 in inventory at the moment.

Muhabat is a skilled entrepreneur. When she started this trade, she decided to implement basic concepts of integrity and hard work in her business to reach ultimate success. This laid a firm foundation for winning results and Muhabat has obviously been a successful small entrepreneur. However, she doesn’t want to stop. She would like to continue seeing her venture grow. Today she is requesting a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD) for 4 months to increase her assorted inventory and possibly open a new vending location in the future. With your help this will be possible.

loans.use: Purchasing new fabrics to increase the range of goods.

loans.name: Faizullo

texts.en:
Faizullo I. is 53 years old. He is married and has three children. He is a hard-working man struggling to feed his children and parents (who are living with him) by selling the national fabrics for the national dresses.

Faizullo has a trading place in the center of the local markets of Dushanbe City. Faizullo is trying to have a wide range of goods in order to meet the requirements of his customers and to satisfy the needs of clients with different levels of income.

Faizullo, being a devoted father, is doing the best he can so his children can be well educated and happy. Today Faizullo feels that with more working capital his business could generate more income, so he is asking for a loan of 3000 Somoni ($900 USD) with the term of 4 months to jumpstart the business and raise the family's standard of living. Let's help this incredible father give his children a brighter future.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new fabrics for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.en:
Bahodur M. is married with one daughter. He and his family live in Dushanbe. Bahodur is a private entrepreneur who sells sports footwear in the central city market.

Bahodur is very disciplined. One of his strong characteristics is his ability to listen and persuade, which helps him in his work with customers. Bahodur has been in the market for 10 years. He started as a little boy, helping his mother with her business.

Bahodur‘s main goal is to provide his family with a decent life and a stable future. He has always tried to achieve financial and economic independence and make a career. Bahodur is hoping to see his business flourish and succeed. For this purpose he is asking for a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750 USD) for the term of 12 months. He believes that this loan will be one of the steps toward his goal. Let’s get behind this dedicated father to achieve his goals and he will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: Purchasing new sports footwear for men to sell.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma Dervić is 23 years old and lives in a little village near Te anj. She is a housewife and has a husband who is employed. Alma earns extra income producing and selling vegetables and milk. She has two cows but not enough fodder for them for the winter. That is the reason that she is requesting a loan through WWI in the amount of 1200 KM. She hopes to keeps her cows safely fed and be able to offer milk of good quality.

loans.use: To buy  fodder for her milch cows

loans.name: Alisa

texts.en: Alisa Rakić comes from Te anj. She is married and her husband is employed. She is a housewife and she does a lot of work in agriculture. She produces different sorts of vegetables and some of what she produces she sells and some is for her own use. Beside that she has a cow and goats. She has requested a loan through WWI in the amount of 1200 KM to buy livestock fodder. She hopes that she will sell all her young goats around New Year and be able to buy others to raise.

loans.use: To buy livestock fodder

loans.name: Lutfiya

texts.en:
Lutfiya M. is 29 years old. She is divorced and has 2 children.

Lutfiya has dedicated herself to selling eggs in Dushanbe’s food market for the past 7 years. She has led a difficult life, particularly when she divorced and was unable to find work to replace her husband’s income and support herself. As a result, she decided to invest the small amount of savings that she was able to collect over many years in this business. She has expanded her business with the help of IMON. She has been acquiring greater amounts of eggs, which has helped increase her earnings, albeit very slowly.

Her plans are to invest more in her business through the purchase of additional products to sell. She requests 2600 Somoni ($775 USD) for the term of 12 months. Lutfiya has worked with IMON for over a year and, despite the competition, she is starting to see better results from her endeavors. She proposes to continue with the loans which have so benefited her business.

loans.use: To purchase eggs to expand the business

loans.name: Balkhumor

texts.en:
Balkhumor M. is a 43 year old woman. She is married with three children. 

Surrounded by beautiful and tame cows, Balkhumor carries out her daily work herding the grazing cattle that belong to an educational center in the district of Khoktosh. She has been dedicated to this occupation for the last 13 years along with her dear husband. Balkhumor works as cleaning staff at the same center. Both jobs are very hard and she struggles to offer an adequate education to their three children. She and her husband wish to give each of them the opportunity of superior studies. 

Balkhumor wishes to buy calves for breeding and reproduction so she can have a business of her own. Therefore she is asking for a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1175 USD), which will be repaid in a period of 12 months. Let us help this industrious mother make her dreams come true. She wants to see her beloved children as professionals and with a bright future.

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima Buljubasić comes from Krasevo, a big village near Tesanj. She is a young married women who lives with her husband. Fatima spends her days taking care of her garden. She has a corn field and one old cow. Her cow gave a lot of milk earlier and Fatima used to be able to sell the milk and earn more than now.

Fatima wants to buy another ( younger ) cow so she is requesting a loan through WWI in the amount of 1200 KM. This amount alone is not enough to buy a new cow, but together with the money from selling her old cow, Fatima will be able to buy a younger one.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Sabagul

texts.en:
Sabagul N. is married with three teenage children. She lives in Dushanbe with her family.

Sabagul was laid off from her previous job and had to find a stable source of income to provide for her family. That is how she ended up as an entrepreneur. Presently, Sabagul sells children’s clothing in the central city market. She has been in this trade for 8 years. She offers a large variety of clothing items at a reasonable price.

Sabagul has repaid all of her previous loans from IMON without any delinquencies. Now she requests 3400 Somoni ($1000 USD) for the term of 6 months. She wants to buy additional merchandise in order to increase the range of her goods. Her long-term plan is to open one more vending facility. Moreover, Sabagul is hoping to use the generated profit to help her daughter get a good education at the University. We believe her enthusiasm, motivation and desire to improve her living standards will guarantee prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for kids in order to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Mamuroy

texts.en:
Mamuroy N. is a small entrepreneur from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She is divorced with four children. Her children are the reason for her daily fight for a better life. Being the only bread winner in the family, she sells clothing for teenagers in one of the famous local markets known as the Central Market.

Mamuroy is a very hard-working woman. She always achieves her goals and overcomes different challenges with natural optimism. She is requesting a loan of $900 USD for the term of 18 months to re-stock her inventory. She is hoping to purchase more merchandise at affordable wholesale prices for further retail sale.

Mamuroy's only dream is to ensure her children have a good education and to make them happy. We believe Mamuroy’s integrity and the consistent growth of her venture in the past years can guarantee further stable expansion of her trade and timely loan repayment. The well-being of this family is in your hands.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing to re-stock her inventory

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.en:
Mehriniso S. is 40 years old. She lives with her spouse and her children. Every day, she goes to work very early in the morning. She wants to get ahead and achieve her goal of having her five children successfully finish school and enter University.

Her business is located in the local market called “Labi Daryo” and she sells clothes for women. Thanks to the support of her spouse and her own efforts, she was able to expand her business, which began with little inventory and in a small space. Her business is now in a bigger space and she has a large base of clients. With the loan of 3400 Somoni ($1000 USD), which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a greater variety of clothing styles to sell. She will also buy clothing for a variety of occasions and even purchase a few specific requests of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for women in order to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.en:
Tursunoy Y. is 49 years old. She is married and the mother of four children.

Tursunoy's lack of a stable job and the slow productivity of her husband's business as a teacher didn't leave enough money to pay the expenses of their home and of their little daughter. This was the reason that Tursunoy decided to start her own business 13 years ago. Now she sells the fabrics of the national dresses.

Little by little, she has made her business grow by offering her clients the option to pay for their goods in installments. Now her business is running normally. However, she would like to continue bettering herself and her business so her situation will be stable in the future, in case something bad should happen. She is asking for a loan of 3500 Somoni ($1025 USD) that she will pay back in 4 months. With this money, Tursunoy will be able to buy seasonal fabrics for the national dresses. The power to help her business grow is in your hands.

loans.use: To purchase new fabrics to increase the range of goods for sale

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Mrs. Chan S. is a villager in Khsae Tor Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Chan S. is 32 years old and the mother of two children who are both attending the local school. She is a farmer who earns a small revenue from cultivating rice on her little lot of land. She now wants to increase her revenue so she decided to ask for a loan to buy another piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Um Siem, is a primary teacher who can make $30 per month to support the family.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Shamigul

texts.en:
Shamigul Y. is 45 years old. She is a widow and has two children.

Shamigul has never had anyone's assistance in helping her and her children, especially after the death of her husband 5 years ago. Therefore, she has been working to grow her business to support her family. Shamigul sells fuels - petrol and diesel fuel. This has been her only source of income to support and educate her children. It has not been easy for her to shoulder the entire responsibility for her family. However, her love for her children is what drives her forward from day to day. Now her elder son helps her with the business.

Today Shamigul is requesting a loan of 2200 Somoni ($650 USD) that will be used to increase her goods. She has a good supply of orders for her fuels. She promises to return this amount in 12 months. The well-being of this brave woman’s family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of her business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: To purchase inventory to increase the goods available for sale

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena J. ić is a modern young girl who comes from Doboj. She is 21 and lives alone. She works in a popular cafe in the town. Working there, she meets many people her age and that gives her an opportunity to earn somewhat more. She sells cosmetics and ornaments.

Magdalena goes, from time to time, to a big marketplace to purchase her reserves of products. She doesn't earn much but enough to live on. Taking a loan through WWI in the amount of 600 KM will allow her to buy somewhat bigger reserves of the products that she sells.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for re-sale

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann T. is a 47 year old widow with five children in the Kor Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Two of her children hold a junior position in a company, while two others are attending the local school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Mrs. Vann T. owns a rice mill and earns a small income to support her family. Even though her family is involved in different businesses, they continue live in an old house that is in poor condition. In order to improve these conditions, Mrs. Vann T. has decided to ask for a loan to build a new house to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Choeurng

texts.en:
Mr. Choeurng S. is a villager in Prey Kosh Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He is a construction worker who can earn only a meager income to support his family. In order to support his family, Mr. Choeurng S. decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings to buy a motorbike to start a new motorbike taxi business.

His wife, Mrs. Em Sokunthea, is a garment factory worker. Mr. Choeurng S. is 31 years old and the father of three children who are all too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to start a new motorbike taxi business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok N. is a villager in Prey Leak Neng Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her household. Her husband, Mr. Chan Pon, is a farmer. They have four children: three of whom are employed in a garment factory, while the other is a cow breeder. Although Mrs. Sok N.'s family members are involved in different businesses, they still cannot afford to build a new bathroom their household. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to build a new bathroom to improve her family's living conditions.

Her husband is also present in the photo.

loans.use: To build a bathroom

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mrs. Sek S. is a farmer in Peam Prochum Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is 49 years old and the mother of two children, both of whom are attending the local school. In her plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile, thus affecting her crop growth. To solve this problem, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to improve her field conditions. Her husband, Mr. Chan Song, is a palm juice collector who gathers palms to process into sugar and wine. Aside from this business, he is also a pig breeder. Previously, Mrs. Sek S. had obtained a loan from AMK to buy piglets for her husband's business. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Renata

texts.en:
Renata B. ić was born in 1974 and she comes from Te anj. Renata`s husband is employed but she is not; she is a housewife. She keeps busy in her garden and field. Beside that, she has chickens which give her eggs and she sells them.

Renata wants to expand her business by buying more poultry. That is the reason for taking her first loan through WWI in the amount of 600 KM. Renata will buy chicks and food for them. She already has her customers for the chicken meat ( she sells them the eggs already ). Renata hopes to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: To buy more poultry

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mrs. Bun N. is 44 years old mother of three in Trapaing Chum Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Two of her children are employed in a garment factory, while the other is attending the local school. Mrs. Bun N. works as a farmer, but she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile, thus badly affecting her crop growth. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Bun N. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to improve her field conditions to produce a better crop. Her husband, Mr. Mean Lorn, is a firewood seller who earns a small income to support his family. Her husband is located on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers to improve field conditions

loans.name: Prom

texts.en: Mrs. Prom N. is a 44 year old mother of three in Trapaing Chum Village, Kampong Chhnang Province.
